awd_titl_txt: Measurements of Hydrogen Oxide (HOx) Radical Chemistry Above and Below the Forest Canopy
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will improve understanding of the influence of forest emissions on the production of ozone in the atmosphere.  Currently, atmospheric chemistry models tend to overpredict the concentration of ozone in forested environments.  Atmospheric radicals, such as the hydroxyl radical (OH), play an important role in the chemistry of the atmosphere and in the production of ozone.  This project includes additional measurements and modeling of atmospheric radicals to improve the understanding of atmospheric chemistry and for improving models that predict the production of ozone and fine particulates in the atmosphere.

The following questions regarding the measurement and modeling of HOx radicals in forested environments will be addressed: (1) What is the source of the interference associated with measurements of OH radical concentrations in forest environments and can it be minimized? (2) How well do we understand the sources, sinks, and recycling of HOx radicals in forest environments? and (3) How does below canopy radical chemistry and transport impact the above canopy environment?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The hydroxyl radical (OH) and peroxy radicals, both the hydroperoxy (HO2) and organic peroxy radicals (RO2) play a central role in the chemistry of the atmosphere. In addition to controlling the lifetimes of many important trace gases such as methane, OH radical reactions initiate the oxidation of carbon monoxide and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) which in the presence of nitrogen oxides (NOx) can lead to the production of ozone and secondary aerosols in the atmosphere, the primary components of photochemical smog. Recent ambient measurements of OH and HO2 radicals have revealed serious discrepancies with model predictions, especially in forested environments with high emissions of biogenic VOCs, and current atmospheric chemistry models tend to overpredict the concentration of ozone in these environments.

Intellectual Merit. The inability of current models of atmospheric chemistry to explain measured concentrations of radicals in forested environments has important implications to current issues of air quality and climate change, as it questions our understanding of the contribution of biogenic emissions to the production of ozone and aerosols in the atmosphere as well as our ability to predict how well the atmosphere will be able to remove methane and other greenhouse gases in the future. Current atmospheric chemistry models tend to overpredict surface ozone levels over the forested areas of the eastern United States. One possible explanation is that shading from the forest canopy and turbulence results in low radical production below the forest canopy leading to ozone destruction and net loss of ozone within the forest canopy.

To determine whether radical chemistry and ozone production is suppressed inside forest canopies, measurements of OH and HO2 radicals were conducted both at the Indiana University Research and Teaching Preserve Field Lab in Bloomington and the PROPHET (Program for Research on Oxidants: Photochemistry, Emissions, and Transport) forest site at the University of Michigan Biological Station in northern Michigan. These measurements occurred in deciduous forests, where the dominant biogenic VOC emission is isoprene. Measured concentrations below the forest canopy at both sites were similar to that measured above the canopy, suggesting that significant radical chemistry is occurring in the below canopy environment. Models of the chemistry below the forest canopy underestimated the OH radical concentrations, suggesting that there were missing sources of radicals not included in the models, but were able to reproduce the measured HO2 concentrations. In contrast, models of the chemistry above the forest canopy were able to reproduce the measured OH radical concentrations, while overestimating the measured HO2 and RO2 concentrations, suggesting that there may be missing radical loss process not included in models. This missing radical loss process may explain why models tend to overestimate ozone concentrations over the forests in eastern US.

We also conducted below canopy measurements of OH and HO2 radicals in the Manitou Experimental forest in Colorado. In contrast to the measurements in Indiana and Michigan, these measurements were conducted in a coniferous forest where methybutenol is the primary biogenic VOC emission. Model simulations underestimated the measured OH and HO2 concentrations, suggesting that there may be a significant missing radical source in this forest environment not included in models. Additional measurements of nitrous acid (HONO) at this site, which is an important source of OH radicals, indicated a significant source from the surface, perhaps due to microbial production at this site. Including the measured HONO concentrations in the model improves the agreement with the measured concentration of OH, but still underestimates the concentration of peroxy radicals in the morning. These results suggest that models may underestimate ozone production over these forests.

Broader Impacts. The inability of current models of atmospheric chemistry to explain measured concentrations of radicals in forested areas has important implications to current issues of air quality as it questions our understanding of the chemistry of the atmosphere under conditions typical of rural and remote regions. Improving our understanding of the chemistry of these areas will help lead to more effective control strategies for the production of ozone and fine particulates in the atmosphere. In this study, measurements of peroxy radicals in some forest environments were found to be higher than model predictions, suggesting that current models may be underestimating ozone production in these regions due to a missing radical source. In other forests, measurements of peroxy radicals were found to be significantly lower than model predictions, especially in rural areas with very low concentrations of NOx, suggesting that current models may be overestimating ozone production in these regions due to a missing radical loss process. Measurements below the forest canopy revealed concentrations of radicals that were similar to that found above the forest canopy, suggesting that significant radical chemistry not included in current models is occurring in the shaded area below the canopy that could impact ozone above the canopy.
